instanceMethods.name: onDidUpdate
instanceMethods.summary:
Subscribe to be notified asynchronously whenever markers are
created, updated, or destroyed on this layer. *Prefer this method for
optimal performance when interacting with layers that could contain large
numbers of markers.*
instanceMethods.description:
Subscribe to be notified asynchronously whenever markers are
created, updated, or destroyed on this layer. *Prefer this method for
optimal performance when interacting with layers that could contain large
numbers of markers.*

Subscribers are notified once, asynchronously when any number of changes
occur in a given tick of the event loop. You should re-query the layer
to determine the state of markers in which you're interested in. It may
be counter-intuitive, but this is much more efficient than subscribing to
events on individual markers, which are expensive to deliver.

arguments.name: callback
arguments.description: A {Function} that will be called with no arguments when changes occur on this layer.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Disposable}.

absolutely necessary.

arguments.name: callback
arguments.description: A {Function} that will be called with a {TextEditorMarker} whenever a new marker is created.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Disposable}.

instanceMethods.name: markScreenRange
instanceMethods.summary: Create a marker with the given screen range.
instanceMethods.description: Create a marker with the given screen range.

children.name: reversed
children.description: {Boolean} Creates the marker in a reversed orientation. (default: false)

children.name: invalidate
children.description:
{String} Determines the rules by which changes to the buffer *invalidate* the marker. (default: 'overlap') It can be any of the following strategies, in order of fragility:
* __never__: The marker is never marked as invalid. This is a good choice for
  markers representing selections in an editor.
* __surround__: The marker is invalidated by changes that completely surround it.
* __overlap__: The marker is invalidated by changes that surround the
  start or end of the marker. This is the default.
* __inside__: The marker is invalidated by changes that extend into the
  inside of the marker. Changes that end at the marker's start or
  start at the marker's end do not invalidate the marker.
* __touch__: The marker is invalidated by a change that touches the marked
  region in any way, including changes that end at the marker's
  start or start at the marker's end. This is the most fragile strategy.

children.name: exclusive
children.description: {Boolean} indicating whether insertions at the start or end of the marked range should be interpreted as happening *outside* the marker. Defaults to `false`, except when using the `inside` invalidation strategy or when when the marker has no tail, in which case it defaults to true. Explicitly assigning this option overrides behavior in all circumstances.

children.name: clipDirection
children.description: {String} If `'backward'`, returns the first valid position preceding an invalid position. If `'forward'`, returns the first valid position following an invalid position. If `'closest'`, returns the first valid position closest to an invalid position. Defaults to `'closest'`. Applies to the start and end of the given range.

arguments.name: options
arguments.description: A hash of key-value pairs to associate with the marker. There are also reserved property names that have marker-specific meaning.

returnValues.description: Returns a {DisplayMarker}.

instanceMethods.name: findMarkers
instanceMethods.summary: Find markers in the layer conforming to the given parameters.
instanceMethods.description:
Find markers in the layer conforming to the given parameters.

This method finds markers based on the given properties. Markers can be
associated with custom properties that will be compared with basic equality.
In addition, there are several special properties that will be compared
with the range of the markers rather than their properties.

children.name: startBufferPosition
children.description: Only include markers starting at this {Point} in buffer coordinates.

children.name: endBufferPosition
children.description: Only include markers ending at this {Point} in buffer coordinates.

children.name: startScreenPosition
children.description: Only include markers starting at this {Point} in screen coordinates.

children.name: endScreenPosition
children.description: Only include markers ending at this {Point} in screen coordinates.

children.name: startBufferRow
children.description: Only include markers starting at this row in buffer coordinates.

children.name: endBufferRow
children.description: Only include markers ending at this row in buffer coordinates.

children.name: startScreenRow
children.description: Only include markers starting at this row in screen coordinates.

children.name: endScreenRow
children.description: Only include markers ending at this row in screen coordinates.

children.name: intersectsBufferRowRange
children.description: Only include markers intersecting this {Array}  of `[startRow, endRow]` in buffer coordinates.

children.name: intersectsScreenRowRange
children.description: Only include markers intersecting this {Array}  of `[startRow, endRow]` in screen coordinates.

children.name: containsBufferRange
children.description: Only include markers containing this {Range} in buffer coordinates.

children.name: containsBufferPosition
children.description: Only include markers containing this {Point} in buffer coordinates.

children.name: containedInBufferRange
children.description: Only include markers contained in this {Range} in buffer coordinates.

children.name: containedInScreenRange
children.description: Only include markers contained in this {Range} in screen coordinates.

children.name: intersectsBufferRange
children.description: Only include markers intersecting this {Range} in buffer coordinates.

children.name: intersectsScreenRange
children.description: Only include markers intersecting this {Range} in screen coordinates.

arguments.name: properties
arguments.description: An {Object} containing properties that each returned marker must satisfy. Markers can be associated with custom properties, which are compared with basic equality. In addition, several reserved properties can be used to filter markers based on their current range:

returnValues.description: Returns an {Array} of {DisplayMarker}s

instanceMethods.name: copy
instanceMethods.summary:
Creates and returns a new {DisplayMarker} with the same properties as
this marker.
instanceMethods.description:
Creates and returns a new {DisplayMarker} with the same properties as
this marker.

{Selection} markers (markers with a custom property `type: "selection"`)
should be copied with a different `type` value, for example with
`marker.copy({type: null})`. Otherwise, the new marker's selection will
be merged with this marker's selection, and a `null` value will be
returned.

arguments.name: properties
arguments.description: {Object} properties to associate with the new marker. The new marker's properties are computed by extending this marker's properties with `properties`.

returnValues.description: Returns a {DisplayMarker}.

DisplayMarker.summary:
Represents a buffer annotation that remains logically stationary
even as the buffer changes. This is used to represent cursors, folds, snippet
targets, misspelled words, and anything else that needs to track a logical
location in the buffer over time.
DisplayMarker.description:
Represents a buffer annotation that remains logically stationary
even as the buffer changes. This is used to represent cursors, folds, snippet
targets, misspelled words, and anything else that needs to track a logical
location in the buffer over time.

### DisplayMarker Creation

Use {DisplayMarkerLayer::markBufferRange} or {DisplayMarkerLayer::markScreenRange}
rather than creating Markers directly.

### Head and Tail

Markers always have a *head* and sometimes have a *tail*. If you think of a
marker as an editor selection, the tail is the part that's stationary and the
head is the part that moves when the mouse is moved. A marker without a tail
always reports an empty range at the head position. A marker with a head position
greater than the tail is in a "normal" orientation. If the head precedes the
tail the marker is in a "reversed" orientation.

### Validity

Markers are considered *valid* when they are first created. Depending on the
invalidation strategy you choose, certain changes to the buffer can cause a
marker to become invalid, for example if the text surrounding the marker is
deleted. The strategies, in order of descending fragility:

* __never__: The marker is never marked as invalid. This is a good choice for
  markers representing selections in an editor.
* __surround__: The marker is invalidated by changes that completely surround it.
* __overlap__: The marker is invalidated by changes that surround the
  start or end of the marker. This is the default.
* __inside__: The marker is invalidated by changes that extend into the
  inside of the marker. Changes that end at the marker's start or
  start at the marker's end do not invalidate the marker.
* __touch__: The marker is invalidated by a change that touches the marked
  region in any way, including changes that end at the marker's
  start or start at the marker's end. This is the most fragile strategy.

See {TextBuffer::markRange} for usage.

instanceMethods.summary: Create a marker at with its head at the given position with no tail.
instanceMethods.description: Create a marker at with its head at the given position with no tail.

children.name: invalidate
children.description:
{String} Determines the rules by which changes to the buffer *invalidate* the marker. (default: 'overlap') It can be any of the following strategies, in order of fragility:
* __never__: The marker is never marked as invalid. This is a good choice for
  markers representing selections in an editor.
* __surround__: The marker is invalidated by changes that completely surround it.
* __overlap__: The marker is invalidated by changes that surround the
  start or end of the marker. This is the default.
* __inside__: The marker is invalidated by changes that extend into the
  inside of the marker. Changes that end at the marker's start or
  start at the marker's end do not invalidate the marker.
* __touch__: The marker is invalidated by a change that touches the marked
  region in any way, including changes that end at the marker's
  start or start at the marker's end. This is the most fragile strategy.

children.name: exclusive
children.description: {Boolean} indicating whether insertions at the start or end of the marked range should be interpreted as happening *outside* the marker. Defaults to `false`, except when using the `inside` invalidation strategy or when when the marker has no tail, in which case it defaults to true. Explicitly assigning this option overrides behavior in all circumstances.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Marker}.

instanceMethods.name: onDidUpdate
instanceMethods.summary:
Subscribe to be notified asynchronously whenever markers are
created, updated, or destroyed on this layer. *Prefer this method for
optimal performance when interacting with layers that could contain large
numbers of markers.*
instanceMethods.description:
Subscribe to be notified asynchronously whenever markers are
created, updated, or destroyed on this layer. *Prefer this method for
optimal performance when interacting with layers that could contain large
numbers of markers.*

Subscribers are notified once, asynchronously when any number of changes
occur in a given tick of the event loop. You should re-query the layer
to determine the state of markers in which you're interested in. It may
be counter-intuitive, but this is much more efficient than subscribing to
events on individual markers, which are expensive to deliver.

arguments.name: callback
arguments.description: A {Function} that will be called with no arguments when changes occur on this layer.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Disposable}.

instanceMethods.name: onDidCreateMarker
instanceMethods.summary:
Subscribe to be notified synchronously whenever markers are created
on this layer. *Avoid this method for optimal performance when interacting
with layers that could contain large numbers of markers.*
instanceMethods.description:
Subscribe to be notified synchronously whenever markers are created
on this layer. *Avoid this method for optimal performance when interacting
with layers that could contain large numbers of markers.*

You should prefer {onDidUpdate} when synchronous notifications aren't
absolutely necessary.

arguments.name: callback
arguments.description: A {Function} that will be called with a {Marker} whenever a new marker is created.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Disposable}.

instanceMethods.summary: Subscribe to be notified synchronously when this layer is destroyed.
instanceMethods.description: Subscribe to be notified synchronously when this layer is destroyed.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Disposable}.

specified by the given point.
instanceMethods.description:
Build and return a new {Point} by traversing the rows and columns
specified by the given point.

This method differs from the direct, vector-style addition offered by
{::translate}. Rather than adding the rows and columns directly, it derives
the new point from traversing in "typewriter space". At the end of every row
traversed, a carriage return occurs that returns the columns to 0 before
continuing the traversal.

instanceMethods.summary:
Invoke the given callback when all marker `::onDidChange`
observers have been notified following a change to the buffer.
instanceMethods.description:
Invoke the given callback when all marker `::onDidChange`
observers have been notified following a change to the buffer.

The order of events following a buffer change is as follows:

* The text of the buffer is changed
* All markers are updated accordingly, but their `::onDidChange` observers
  are not notified.
* `TextBuffer::onDidChange` observers are notified.
* `Marker::onDidChange` observers are notified.
* `TextBuffer::onDidUpdateMarkers` observers are notified.

Basically, this method gives you a way to take action after both a buffer
change and all associated marker changes.

arguments.name: callback
arguments.description: {Function} to be called after markers are updated.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Disposable} on which `.dispose()` can be called to unsubscribe.

instanceMethods.name: markRange
instanceMethods.summary:
Create a marker with the given range in the default marker layer.
This marker will maintain its logical location as the buffer is changed, so
if you mark a particular word, the marker will remain over that word even if
the word's location in the buffer changes.
instanceMethods.description:
Create a marker with the given range in the default marker layer.
This marker will maintain its logical location as the buffer is changed, so
if you mark a particular word, the marker will remain over that word even if
the word's location in the buffer changes.

children.name: reversed
children.description: {Boolean} Creates the marker in a reversed orientation. (default: false)

children.name: invalidate
children.description:
{String} Determines the rules by which changes to the buffer *invalidate* the marker. (default: 'overlap') It can be any of the following strategies, in order of fragility:
* __never__: The marker is never marked as invalid. This is a good choice for
  markers representing selections in an editor.
* __surround__: The marker is invalidated by changes that completely surround it.
* __overlap__: The marker is invalidated by changes that surround the
  start or end of the marker. This is the default.
* __inside__: The marker is invalidated by changes that extend into the
  inside of the marker. Changes that end at the marker's start or
  start at the marker's end do not invalidate the marker.
* __touch__: The marker is invalidated by a change that touches the marked
  region in any way, including changes that end at the marker's
  start or start at the marker's end. This is the most fragile strategy.

children.name: exclusive
children.description: {Boolean} indicating whether insertions at the start or end of the marked range should be interpreted as happening *outside* the marker. Defaults to `false`, except when using the `inside` invalidation strategy or when when the marker has no tail, in which case it defaults to true. Explicitly assigning this option overrides behavior in all circumstances.

arguments.name: properties
arguments.description: A hash of key-value pairs to associate with the marker. There are also reserved property names that have marker-specific meaning.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Marker}.

* __inside__: The marker is invalidated by changes that extend into the

* __touch__: The marker is invalidated by a change that touches the marked

  start or start at the marker's end. This is the most fragile strategy.

instanceMethods.name: undo

instanceMethods.description: Undo the last operation. If a transaction is in progress, aborts it.

instanceMethods.description: Redo the last operation

instanceMethods.name: transact
instanceMethods.summary: Batch multiple operations as a single undo/redo step.
instanceMethods.description:
Batch multiple operations as a single undo/redo step.

Any group of operations that are logically grouped from the perspective of
undoing and redoing should be performed in a transaction. If you want to
abort the transaction, call {::abortTransaction} to terminate the function's
execution and revert any changes performed up to the abortion.

arguments.name: groupingInterval
arguments.description: The {Number} of milliseconds for which this transaction should be considered 'open for grouping' after it begins. If a transaction with a positive `groupingInterval` is committed while the previous transaction is still open for grouping, the two transactions are merged with respect to undo and redo.

arguments.name: fn
arguments.description: A {Function} to call inside the transaction.

instanceMethods.name: clearUndoStack
instanceMethods.summary:
Clear the undo stack. When calling this method within a transaction,
the {::onDidChangeText} event will not be triggered because the information
describing the changes is lost.

instanceMethods.name: createCheckpoint
instanceMethods.summary:
Create a pointer to the current state of the buffer for use
with {::revertToCheckpoint} and {::groupChangesSinceCheckpoint}.
instanceMethods.description:
Create a pointer to the current state of the buffer for use
with {::revertToCheckpoint} and {::groupChangesSinceCheckpoint}.

returnValues.description: Returns a checkpoint value.

instanceMethods.name: revertToCheckpoint
instanceMethods.summary:
Revert the buffer to the state it was in when the given
checkpoint was created.
instanceMethods.description:
Revert the buffer to the state it was in when the given
checkpoint was created.

The redo stack will be empty following this operation, so changes since the
checkpoint will be lost. If the given checkpoint is no longer present in the
undo history, no changes will be made to the buffer and this method will
return `false`.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Boolean} indicating whether the operation succeeded.

instanceMethods.name: groupChangesSinceCheckpoint
instanceMethods.summary:
Group all changes since the given checkpoint into a single
transaction for purposes of undo/redo.
instanceMethods.description:
Group all changes since the given checkpoint into a single
transaction for purposes of undo/redo.

If the given checkpoint is no longer present in the undo history, no
grouping will be performed and this method will return `false`.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Boolean} indicating whether the operation succeeded.

instanceMethods.name: getChangesSinceCheckpoint
instanceMethods.description:
If the given checkpoint is no longer present in the undo history, this
method will return an empty {Array}.

returnValues.description: Returns a list of changes since the given checkpoint.

Returns an {Array} containing the following change {Object}s:

* `start` A {Point} representing where the change started.
* `oldExtent` A {Point} representing the replaced extent.
* `newExtent`: A {Point} representing the replacement extent.
* `newText`: A {String} representing the replacement text.

For example, the position `[1, 100]` is out of bounds if the line at row 1 is
only 10 characters long, and it would be clipped to `(1, 10)`.

returnValues.description:

{Range} if the given range is out-of-bounds.

only 10 characters long, and it would be clipped to (1, 10)

returnValues.description:

the given position.
